item.content:encoded:
As I work on the next release of Eldiron, I‚Äôll post progress screenshots along the way. Here are two shots of the terrain modeling tools in action.

In the first screenshot, you can see how procedural nodes can be applied to sectors and linedefs to deform and colorize the terrain. For example, we flatten the ground and apply a stone texture, while the linedef creates a smooth path into the mountains.

The second screenshot shows the new terrain tool, where we can sculpt the terrain using brushes. Rendering with terrain modifiers happens asynchronously in a background thread, providing a smooth and responsive editing experience.

item.content:encoded:
As I‚Äôm working on the next release of Eldiron, I wanted to share a quick update on what‚Äôs happening behind the scenes. I originally planned to release new versions every 2‚Äì3 weeks, but this round is taking a bit longer‚ÄîI‚Äôm deep in core systems that need to be just right before moving forward.

Render Graph‚Äã

I‚Äôve been integrating the new render graph system, which defines how the scene is drawn using a node-based approach. This allows plugging in effects like fog, ambient lighting, or even a fully procedural sky. More interestingly, this system ties directly into the map‚Äôs geometry‚Äîvertices, linedefs, and sectors.

You can now attach nodes directly to geometry to define local effects like lighting or fog, tweak terrain blending, or control glossiness and reflection on tiles. These graphs are reusable across multiple areas, making it easy to organize logic and effects in a modular way.

This isn't just visual fluff‚Äîeventually, these nodes will also drive gameplay interactions. Think of a node that defines a magical barrier, a trigger zone, or a destructible structure. The goal is to unify rendering, behavior, and logic into a single editable system.

And yes‚Äîthis applies not just to 3D but also to 2D and isometric modes. The same systems work across all views, which keeps things consistent and flexible.

Terrain System‚Äã

The new terrain tool lets you sculpt elevation with custom brushes‚Äîraise, lower, smooth, or roughen areas as you see fit. Tiles and materials blend automatically using rules, so you can paint smooth transitions and beautiful terrain with minimal effort.

All of this ties into the render graph too, which means terrain isn‚Äôt just a visual element‚Äîit can be procedural, dynamic, and reactive.

The inspiration is somewhere between ‚Äúretro charming‚Äù and ‚Äúearly WoW Vanilla‚Äù‚Äînatural, stylized, and smooth, but still performant and easy to work with.

Asynchronous Streaming Terrain and Geometry‚Äã

To support massive maps, terrain and geometry are now chunked and streamed in and out as needed. Unlike a game engine that only cares about the player‚Äôs position, Eldiron Creator has to update everything live as you edit.

That means background threads rebuild chunks, update render data, blend tiles, and apply node graphs without freezing the UI. It‚Äôs been a lot of low-level work, but it‚Äôs finally paying off‚Äîterrain edits feel smooth, and you can paint or modify geometry interactively.

What‚Äôs Next‚Äã

I‚Äôm currently working on the first pass of procedural path nodes‚Äîletting you carve winding roads and trails that modify elevation and materials based on rules. These will connect with the graph system too, opening up possibilities for bridges, stairs, or terrain-aware gameplay triggers.

‚Äî

That‚Äôs it for now! Thanks again for following along‚Äîand for your support, especially on Patreon. The next version will be out once it‚Äôs stable and fun to use.

Take care, Markus

item.title: Eldiron v0.8.23 Released ‚Äî Procedural Materials!
item.description: Eldiron v0.8.23 is now available, introducing support for procedural materials.
item.content:encoded:
Eldiron v0.8.23 is now available, introducing support for procedural materials.

The new material system allows you to assign node-based effects to geometry, enabling tileable, unique materials for use in both 2D and 3D maps ‚Äî fully integrated within Eldiron.

Current node types include color, distance-based gradients, and noise overlays. Additional nodes and advanced features will follow in upcoming releases.

You can now generate tiles directly from your maps, making Eldiron a fully self-sufficient game creation environment.

New in v0.8.23‚Äã

  • Clipboard functionality for geometry (cut, copy, paste) in the map editor
  • Fog-based distance fading for 3D rendering
  • New region-based configuration system
  • Numerous fixes and general improvements

This release continues the path toward a complete retro RPG creation toolkit ‚Äî more updates are coming soon.
